Get Started

Source: vignettes/report.Rmd
report.Rmd

Installation

First, install R. Then, run the following in the console:

install.packages("devtools")
devtools::install_github("neuropsychology/report")
library("report")

Functions

The report package works in a two steps fashion. First, creating a report object with the report() function (which takes different arguments depending on the type of object you are reporting). Then, this report can be displayed either textually, using to_text(), or as a table, using to_table(). Moreover, you can also access a more detailed (but less digest) version of the report using to_fulltext() and to_fulltable(). Finally, to_values() makes it easy to access all the internals of a model.

Supported Objects

Dataframes

r <- report(iris)
to_text(r)
r <- report(iris)
print(to_text(r), width=100)
## The data contains 150 observations of the following variables:
##   - Sepal.Length: Mean = 5.84, SD = 0.83, [4.30, 7.90].
##   - Sepal.Width: Mean = 3.06, SD = 0.44, [2.00, 4.40].
##   - Petal.Length: Mean = 3.76, SD = 1.77, [1.00, 6.90].
##   - Petal.Width: Mean = 1.20, SD = 0.76, [0.10, 2.50].
##   - Species: 3 levels: setosa (n = 50); versicolor (n = 50) and virginica (n = 50).
## [1] "The data contains 150 observations of the following variables:\n  - Sepal.Length: Mean = 5.84, SD = 0.83, [4.30, 7.90].\n  - Sepal.Width: Mean = 3.06, SD = 0.44, [2.00, 4.40].\n  - Petal.Length: Mean = 3.76, SD = 1.77, [1.00, 6.90].\n  - Petal.Width: Mean = 1.20, SD = 0.76, [0.10, 2.50].\n  - Species: 3 levels: setosa (n = 50); versicolor (n = 50) and virginica (n = 50)."
to_table(r)
Variable Level n_Obs Mean SD Min Max n_Missing Skewness Kurtosis
Species setosa 50
Species versicolor 50
Species virginica 50
Petal.Length 150 3.758 1.7653 1.0 6.9 0 -0.2721 -1.395

Grouped Dataframes

library(dplyr)

r <- iris %>% 
  group_by(Species) %>% 
  report(median = TRUE, range = FALSE)  # Display only the Median and MAD

to_fulltext(r)
## The data contains 150 observations, grouped by Species, of the following variables:
## - setosa (n = 50):
##   - Sepal.Length: Mean = 5.01, SD = 0.35, Median = 5.00, MAD = 0.30, Range =, [4.30, 5.80], 0
## missing.
##   - Sepal.Width: Mean = 3.43, SD = 0.38, Median = 3.40, MAD = 0.37, Range =, [2.30, 4.40], 0 missing.
##   - Petal.Length: Mean = 1.46, SD = 0.17, Median = 1.50, MAD = 0.15, Range =, [1.00, 1.90], 0
## missing.
##   - Petal.Width: Mean = 0.25, SD = 0.11, Median = 0.20, MAD = 0.00, Range =, [0.10, 0.60], 0 missing.
## - versicolor (n = 50):
##   - Sepal.Length: Mean = 5.94, SD = 0.52, Median = 5.90, MAD = 0.52, Range =, [4.90, 7.00], 0
## missing.
##   - Sepal.Width: Mean = 2.77, SD = 0.31, Median = 2.80, MAD = 0.30, Range =, [2.00, 3.40], 0 missing.

Correlations and t-tests

report(cor.test(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Petal.Length))
## The Pearson's product-moment correlation between iris$Sepal.Length and iris$Petal.Length is positive, significant and large (r = 0.87, p < .001).
report(t.test(iris$Sepal.Length, iris$Petal.Length))
## The Welch Two Sample t-test suggests that the difference between iris$Sepal.Length and iris$Petal.Length (mean of x = 5.84, mean of y = 3.76, difference = 2.09) is significant (t(211.54) = 13.10, 95% CI [1.77, 2.40], p < .001).

Linear Models (LMs)

model <- lm(Sepal.Length ~ Petal.Length + Species, data=iris)
r <- report(model)

to_text(r)
## We fitted a linear model to predict Sepal.Length with Petal.Length and Species. The model's explanatory power is substantial (R2 = 0.84, adj. R2 = 0.83). The model's intercept is at 3.68. Within this model:
## 
##   - The effect of Petal.Length is positive and can be considered as very large and significant (beta = 0.90, 95% CI [0.78, 1.03], p < .001, std. beta = 1.93).
##   - The effect of Species (versicolor) is negative and can be considered as very large and significant (beta = -1.60, 95% CI [-1.98, -1.22], p < .001, std. beta = -1.93).
##   - The effect of Species (virginica) is negative and can be considered as very large and significant (beta = -2.12, 95% CI [-2.66, -1.58], p < .001, std. beta = -2.56).
to_table(r)
Parameter Coefficient CI_low CI_high p Std_Coefficient Fit
1 (Intercept) 3.6835 3.4738 3.893 0 1.497
2 Petal.Length 0.9046 0.7765 1.033 0 1.928
3 Speciesversicolor -1.6010 -1.9833 -1.219 0 -1.933
4 Speciesvirginica -2.1177 -2.6581 -1.577 0 -2.557
6 R2 0.8367
7 R2 (adj.) 0.8334

General Linear Models (GLMs)

model <- glm(vs ~ mpg + cyl, data=mtcars, family="binomial")
r <- report(model)

to_fulltext(r)
## We fitted a logistic model (estimated using ML) to predict vs with mpg and cyl (formula = vs ~ mpg
## + cyl). Standardized parameters were obtained by fitting the model on a standardized version of the
## dataset. Effect sizes were labelled following Chen's (2010) recommendations.
## 
## The model's explanatory power is substantial (Tjur's R2 = 0.67). The model's intercept,
## corresponding to vs = 0, mpg = 0 and cyl = 0, is at 15.97 (SE = 11.02, 95% CI [-2.71, 44.69], p >
## .1, std. intercept = -0.60). Within this model:
## 
##   - The effect of mpg is negative and can be considered as small and not significant (beta = -0.16,
## SE = 0.24, 95% CI [-0.71, 0.34], p > .1, std. beta = -0.98).
##   - The effect of cyl is negative and can be considered as large and significant (beta = -2.15, SE =
## 1.08, 95% CI [-5.19, -0.54], p < .05, std. beta = -3.84).
to_fulltable(r)
Parameter Coefficient SE CI_low CI_high z df_residual p Std_Coefficient Fit
1 (Intercept) 15.9714 11.0224 -2.7094 44.6936 1.4490 29 0.1473 -0.6012
2 mpg -0.1633 0.2399 -0.7098 0.3374 -0.6807 29 0.4961 -0.9842
